Start: ^Student: "Socrates! I have seen the truth! The world we live in is but a shadow—an illusion! My friends refuse to believe me. How can I make them see the light?"
^"Tell them there's free wine outside the cave. Works every time."
^"Drag them out! They’ll thank you later."
PathA: ^Student: "But what if they refuse to listen? What if they mock me, dismiss me?"
^"If they refuse, let them stay in darkness."
^"Tell them the Oracle of Delphi said the real world has better wine and sun"
^"True wisdom is patience; they must come to it themselves."
PathB: ^Student: "Yes! But… what if they resist? Must I fight to free them from ignorance?"
^"Maybe I was wrong. They must take the first step willingly."
^"Just tell them you saw a philosopher giving away free wine outside."
^"Ignorance is comfortable; they will fight to stay."
PathC: ^"If they don’t believe you, you can just go home and drink some wine."
^"No, it was a joke. Let them come to knowledge, not be tricked into it."
Outcome1: ^Student nods, accepting the wisdom. Socrates gains reputation
Outcome2: ^Student frowns, disappointed in Socrates’ pragmatism. Citizens will be less likely to aid him in future.
Outcome3: ^Student laughs and decides absurdity might open minds. Students talk about Socrates humor. He is now deemed to be a funniest guy in the city.
